I have this and a bunch of essential oils and coconut oil and I would like to make a hair cream for curly haired people. I have been buying a coconut cream and I’m wondering if I can make it

Below are two proven, kitchen-scale formulas you can make with the ingredients in your photo (BTMS “Emulsifire”, cocoa-butter chips, Castile soap base) plus the coconut oil and essential oils you already have.  Pick the one that best matches how you like to style curls, or make both and see which your hair loves.

---

## 1) Whipped Curl Butter (no water, no preservative)

| Ingredient | % | 100 g test batch | Why it’s here |
|------------|---|-----------------|---------------|
| Cocoa-butter chips | 40 % | 40 g | Seals moisture, adds weight & definition |
| Coconut oil | 40 % | 40 g | Penetrating oil for softness & shine |
| Castor oil (optional) | 10 % | 10 g | Extra slip & frizz control |
| Vari-BTMS* | 5 % | 5 g | Light conditioning & helps butter feel less greasy |
| Vitamin E | 0.5 % | 0.5 g | Antioxidant for oils |
| Essential-oil blend | 0.5 % | 0.5 g | Scent & scalp benefits |

\*Vari-BTMS is a vegan BTMS-25-style emulsifying conditioner (behentrimonium methosulfate + cetearyl alcohol).

### Method  
1. **Melt** cocoa butter, coconut oil, castor oil & BTMS in a heat-safe beaker over a simmering water bath (≈70 °C).  
2. **Cool & whip**: Once the mixture reaches a thick “trace” (~35 °C), whip with an electric whisk until light and fluffy.  
3. **Add cool-down** ingredients (vit E, EOs), whip 20 s more.  
4. **Jar & label.** Store away from heat; lasts 6-9 months because there’s no water.

### How to use  
Rake a pea-size through dripping-wet hair as the “C” step in L.O.C./L.C.O. It’s rich—start sparingly!

Modern Wifestyle’s long-time curl-butter recipe (150 g shea, 90 g coconut, castor & tea-tree) uses the same ratios, showing the approach is curl-friendly. citeturn5view0

---

## 2) Lightweight Leave-In Curl Cream (emulsified, water-based)

| Ingredient | % | 100 g batch | Phase |
|------------|---|------------|-------|
| **Phase A – Water** |
| Distilled water | 67 % | 67 g | Hydration |
| Vegetable glycerin | 3 % | 3 g | Humectant |
| **Phase B – Oils & emulsifier** |
| Coconut oil | 10 % | 10 g | Nourish & reduce frizz |
| Cocoa-butter chips | 5 % | 5 g | Light hold, occlusion |
| Vari-BTMS | 6 % | 6 g | Primary conditioner & emulsifier (ideal 4–8 %)citeturn2view0 |
| Cetyl or cetearyl alcohol* | 2 % | 2 g | Viscosity & velvety feel (optional) |
| **Phase C – Cool-down** |
| Broad-spectrum preservative** | 1 % | 1 g | Safety |
| Panthenol (pro-vit B5) | 1.5 % | 1.5 g | Strength & sheen |
| Essential-oil blend | 0.5 % | 0.5 g | Scent/scalp soothing |
| Citric-acid 10 % solution | q.s. | adjust pH 4.5–5.5 |

\*If you don’t have a fatty alcohol on hand, simply increase water by 2 %.  
\**Look for Ecocert-approved options like Geogard ECT or Optiphen ND at ~1 %.

### Method  
1. **Sanitise** all utensils with 5 % bleach solution, rinse & dry.  
2. **Heat** Phase A and Phase B separately to 70 °C.  
3. **Combine & emulsify**: Pour Phase B into Phase A. Stick-blend 1 min, then stir while it cools.  
4. **Cool-down**: <40 °C, whisk in Phase C, check/adjust pH.  
5. **Bottle** in a pump or squeeze tube.  Shelf life ≈ 4–6 months (preservative + correct pH).

### How to use  
Work a nickel-size through damp curls, scrunch, then air-dry or diffuse.  Gives feather-light moisture, definition, and a touch of hold without crunch.

> *Why the Castile soap?*  
> It’s great for a gentle co-wash cleanser (3 parts soap base : 1 part water, add 1 % essential oils).  Skip it in leave-ins—the alkaline pH (~9) would undo the conditioning work.

---

### Customising for different curl patterns

| Need | Tweak |
|------|-------|
| Tighter coils craving extra weight | +2 % cocoa butter, –2 % water |
| Fine waves that flatten easily | Drop cocoa butter to 2 % & coconut oil to 6 % |
| Protein-loving hair | Swap 1 % water for hydrolysed quinoa, rice, or keratin |

---

### Safety & storage tips
* **Patch-test** on inner arm 24 h before first use.  
* Keep utensils scrupulously clean—water + oils is prime mold food.  
* If you add fresh aloe gel or food ingredients, **refrigerate and toss after a week** or use a stronger preservative.

Enjoy experimenting—once you try your own fresh curl cream, the store-bought tub may never feel as good again!
